TiVo Bolt dramatically improved my Verizon FiOS TV experience. Love it!!	I am comparing TiVo Bolt with standard Verizon FiOS 320Gb DVR (not new, more expensive Quantum FiOS).Pros:1. I am not paying $28 per month to Verizon for using outdated DVR technology (1 DVR, 1 extra box) - now I am only paying Verizon $5 monthly fee for renting a CableCard in addition to programming fees.2. Amazing picture quality. It certainly seems that my TV signal quality (I have a five year old high-end 1080p Sony Bravia TV) improved dramatically.3. TiVo Bolt is way faster and has a materially better UI than my old FiOS DVR.4. I can record four shows simultaneously at the same time v. two using FiOS boxes. Recording options are way more advanced on TiVo and greatly improve the overall experience.5. Ability to search for your desired content, be it shows, movies or whatever else across all of your services (Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, inter alia) is revolutionary. To that extend, I highly recommend getting a TiVo Slide Pro Remote which has a sensor-activated backlit keyboard and a Search button.6. TiVo Mini works extremely well and has no monthly fees whatsoever7. QuickMode works well but it takes time getting used to.8. The device itself is small, sleek and sexy.9. TiVO recording can be pulled up using Amazon Fire / Amazon Fire Stick allowing kids to watch recorded shows on secondary TVs (however see below)10. I now have three times (3x) more space to play with on my DVR.So-so:1. Skip Mode, which fully skips commercials with a click of a button is incredible when it is available. In my experience, it is available only on ~33% of the shows I

Best STB/DVR for Supported Cable Systems	TiVo as the superior Set Top Box/DVR option:I've had plenty of STB/DVR boxes from the likes of Motorola and Atlanta Scientific over the years and they ranged from bad to awful. Big, clunky, and feature-limited boxes with horrid program guides. Technology has marched on and these beasts had hardly advanced in 20 years. The X1 platform is the first significant improvement, but follows the same tired and user-hostile recipe- including monthly rental charges for the box. I recently lived in an area where the local cable company gave up on the proprietary boxes and issued their customers TiVos (Premiere model) instead. Prior to this, I had no experience with or interest in having a TiVo. I was a total convert. Then I moved back to a Comcast location and totally missed the TiVo. So I did some research and bought the 500GB TiVo Bolt. Now there are plenty of cost-breakdown analyses out there and you will save money in the long run, but I'm not going to focus on that here. Getting the CableCard from Comcast was painless, other than having to go to one of their storefronts and take a number and wait. Also painless was the setup- call their special number for CableCard setups- 877-405-2298, otherwise, you will endure pain (you have been warned).What usually turns people away from TiVo is that the box is essentially useless without subscribing to TiVo Service. It's not an insignificant cost and needs to be factored into your decision. The Bolt (at time of writing) includes the first year of service, but is then $15/mo or $150/year or $600 for the lifetime of the Bolt device. So you have the
Five Stars	Excellent
Five Stars	Love that skip mode on my Bolt.  Features great and easy to use.

Stop renting your DVR and paying taxes every month. This works great and is fun to use!	We decided to reduce our cable bill has much as possible by buying our own equipment last year. We selected the TiVo Bolt because it was 4K compatible and because the guide and search features across all the platforms we use, Netflix, Amazon Prime, and Hulu, was included. We've had it almost a year and I couldn't be happier. It's very intuitive to use and I love accessing my DVR in the bedroom using my Galaxy and headphones at night with the TiVo app.The ability to skip commercials with many recorded shows and to increase the play back speed without decreasing sound legibility on programs like Antiques Roadshow is a great timesaver (and I don't fall asleep watching slow talking shows as much anymore). Occasionally, the unit will stop functioning, but his is usually after one of our too frequent Florida power outages. After contacting customer service, which was a good experience, I learned to just re-boot, the answer to most of life's electronic problems, and was back on line quickly. After 10 months, the unit paid for itself in DVR rental fees. I pay about $5.00 a month for a cable card, but that's nothing compared to $25.00 plus taxes on a unit that's not nearly as powerful and fun to use at the Bolt.We didn't buy the lifetime service for the guide because I was a bit nervous not knowing how long our box would last. I will probably kick myself if we're paying a guide fee that will start this November for two years, because that's the pay off point. By then, though, I may be tempted to get the latest and greatest new Bolt.

Worth it for skip feature alone!	My TiVo was about nine years old, and we had it on an older TV set. When we finally updated to a HD TV my old TiVo couldn't handle 1080p, and if a show isn't on the TiVo we're pretty much just not going to watch. I was hesitant to update the TiVo because my goal is to get rid of cable eventually, but I'm glad I did. I know there may have been good TiVos after my old one, but I think this one is the only one with skip capability and I LOVE IT. If I show doesn't have skip I get irritated that I have to manually fast forward through the commercials. And the upgrade of how many shows we can record at the same time is helpful. We don't keep movies etc on the TiVo so we didn't need the higher capacity and we find there is enough storage for what we need, just a few shows a week that we delete as we watch. If you like to keep shows and movies too re-watch it would be worth it to get the higher capacity.

Love Love Love this device	Love Love Love this device.  I can "cut the chord" and record (and pre-set recordings) for all HD broadcast shows.  Especially handy during college football and basketball seasons.  Never miss a game (especially since Sling rarely has any games in replay!).  Easy to use user interface.  Easy set up (I mean VERY easy).  I set my entire TIVO box in about 30 minutes including "cycling" times and connecting HD OTA antenna.  Great multi-functional remote that takes over TV, live streaming, and OTA broadcast functionality (except if you have Sling which requires ROKU etc).  If you are thinking of cutting the chord and minimize streaming services/costs AND you don't want to wait until Hulu posts a certain show (or doesn't at all like "Quantico" that has to record OTA or with a special subscription to a cable company affiliated with ABC!!) then this is a GREAT option to "cut the chord" with cable companies and allow you to only subscribe/purchase the minimum streaming services to get exclusive stuff like ESPN and Fox. With the TIVO Bolt, I've cut my cable costs by about 70% --- currently have Sling $20 (for ESPN mainly-- requires a ROKU stick that you can get for free from Sling), HULU w/ Showtime add-on and commercial free option $21, Netflix for certain Netflix only shows $8.  My Amazon Prime membership I have for my purchases includes Amazon video so it's a "sunk cost" so I don't really include it as a "streaming cost" since I'd have Amazon regardless of what comes with it.  My Internet access for 40mbps is $35/month.  All in all I spend about $84/month for internet and streaming costs.  PLUS with

Excellent Alternative to Time Warner Cable's DVR and Guide	Rarely, do I find a mix of technology and support that is worth a 5-star rating.  However, after only a week of having one, the Tivo BOLT (and an accompanying Mini) have made the list.There's a lot of talk about "cutting the cord" with content providers, and we did that for about a week.  While the "cord" remained partially connected (for Internet access), we dropped all TV content opting for the chance to dive head-strong into antennas.  Quickly, we found ourselves futzing with antenna direction, getting one that would rotate, and finally giving up after visions of the 1950's dad holding bunny ears just right to see The Ed Sullivan show.  While the off-the-air broadcasts of local channels works, it's just not reliable. Reception suffered from pixelation, broken frames, and jittery picture from even the strongest signals which were also seriously affected by wind and storms.  Our location may not have been the best without hoisting a 50' antenna (which I wasn't willing to do).However, partially adding-back content with the use of a CableCARD has effectively allowed us to get the local channels and some that we were used to watching, while cutting our monthly costs significantly:  renting two DVRs ($12.99ea), the DVR fee for each ($8.50), the "Guide" fee ($3.25x2 -- what?  shouldn't this have been free with the service?), taxes and surcharges (what??) totaling over $16/month; and you get the picture.  The Tivo pays for itself quickly, and factoring in the annual fee (first year's free) ends up cancelling out renting one DVR (and, forget those other cable company

Let's be honest...	Let's be honest -- TiVo isn't for everyone, but it IS for me and my family.  There are certainly less expensive options, particularly if you're a cord cutter. However, if you are like me, and have wife that watches Discovery ID (or some other cable channel) AND Netflix constantly and has ZERO tolerance for input switching or other "technical BS" -- this is the best option.  TiVo just works with everything, and seamlessly integrates cable with online options.  It's also pricey.. but if you're stuck with cable like I am, you may already be paying a stupidly high cable bill.  At that point, just suck it up and buy the stupid thing... you'll be happier for it. Worst part? No doubt about it, its working with your cable company for the cable card, etc.  Again, just suck it up and go for it.  I think you'll be happy you did.They finally got it right with the Bolt.  It did take a while... the Premiere model was slow.  The Roamio was (and is) a great option... but the Bolt fixes what was left. Here's what I liked about it vs. the Roamio: 1) smaller; 2) quieter; 3) 4K (not that it really matters much, yet); 4) gigabit ethernet; 5) 1 year of service included (if you buy before May 2016).  It's not all perfect.. like a lot of technology there are some quirks.  I did have an issue with audio dropouts along with my Sony TV and Sonos Playbar.  I do think it was an issue with the Sony, because when I plugged the optical direct from the TiVo to the Playbar the problem went away... I switch the audio source to PCM on both the TV and the TiVo.  All set.People look at me funny when I tell them I have TiVo... I don't thi

A bit of a pain to set up, a dream once you do!	I had DirecTV for years, and I loved it- the only thing was the price of programming in addition to cable prices started to really add up. I went down to basic cable with Charter.  I found it unusable after all of my years with satellite. The OS of the HD cable box was so dang UGLY and doing everything (On demand, guide, etc) was such an absolute chore.  I knew I needed something new.  I had Tivo back in the day when they were in business with DIrecTV, and I decided to give it a shot.  I read some of the reviews how things were so difficult in dealing with the cable company and the antiquated, dreaded cable card! Let me tell you- it was a bit of a chore. Getting the card was east enough, but you need to have an adapter (provided by Charter) in addition to getting the card. You will need another coax cable to run from the adapter to the TIvo box.  They did not give me one at the cable company, so be aware.  The software of the Tivo did get hung up at 72% while it was downloading the information from the cable- it seems like this was something that has happened to many people.  I called the cable company again and had them unpair and pair the cable card again.  After a bit, it worked, and it's a dream. It does take 1-2 hours to get it all set up.  Be patient, and know that once everything gets put together from the cable company side, it works like a charm.  When you combine this with Amazon Prime, Netflix, and Hulu- you'll be amazed at the amount of content that is beautifully presented and easily accessed.  I can't see a way for it to be better.  Try it, relax, and take t

The Cadillac of DVRs	This is my third TIVO purchase since 2001. I have used other DVRs but I keep coming back to them. This time I cut the cord and use this as a combo receiver and DVR. This company just seems to "get it", their recorders offer more. TV should be simple. This keeps your antenna, various streams, YouTube and even Pandora all off one easy to surf menu. The OnePass options to have a permanent constantly renewing list by genre, TV Show, actor, etc, is just one of many functions that has come standard with Tivos that others are still slow to catch on to, and the new function of commercial skip (where applicable) does what it says it does...jump the entire commercial break with a press of a button and back to the show.The only new function I can't speak to is the Fast Play, which is not an option I would choose to turn on, but for binge watchers I could see how something like that would be useful. If you are cutting the cord and can make the investment, this is worth every penny, easily the Cadillac of DVRs.

Im glad I made the purchase	I was a little reluctant to purchase as the product has not been out very long but I wanted to benefit from the features it has such as 4K and much faster than my old TiVo box and the free 1 yr. service, I could not benefit from the mini with my other TiVo boxes so they cost of ownership made sense to me. I bought this box with 1 year free service and I will purchase a Mini to PR with it which brings my bill down to nothing for 1 year as I will disconnect both of my other TiVo boxes with a savings of about 30 per month and 360 per yr. (which just paid for the Bolt)OK now on to the box and setup.. on my other 2 pervious TiVo boxes the install was painful (mainly on the Comcast side) so I was not thrilled with having to go through that again,  but it was far from that. I went to Comcast and picked up a cable card and went home on popped it in the Bolt, called Comcast to activate the card, while on the phone with them I was on TiVo's site activating the Bolt, about 30 min later without any issues I was up and running.......WOW  that made my day.. thanks TiVo and Comcast for getting this process all dialed in.I have not had much time to play with the box but from what I can see it looks great, I like the channel labels and it is quick, much faster than my other TiVo Boxes.

Awsome!	The best DVR available.  Skip mode is great, one button press to seamlessly cut through the entire commercial segment and it lands you a few seconds before the show resumes.What I like most about the Tivo Bolt is how it incorporates Live TV, DVR, as well as popular streaming services into one easy to use interface.  Want to watch the live Sports game?  Bam, ok you're done.  Want to watch something from Netflix or Amazon Video?, you no longer have to switch inputs or mess around with another piece of hardware like a Roku or AppleTV.  The Tivo Bolt lets you watch shows from Netflix, Amazon and others just as easy as if you were going to a Live TV station.It's a game changer device IMO.  Combine the Bolt with Mini's around the home and you now have a unified media network that will stream LiveTV, RecordedTV around the house and also play stuff from the best streaming services.So much better than having to deal with the punitive pricing structure of Cable and Satellite providers who punish their subscribers for using multiple TV's.

Great substitute for paying cable equipment fees!	Paying $295 a month for Verizon Fios was killing me! And I didn't even have all the movie channels!! I decided to start comparing, Comcast, satellite, etc. and then I stumbled on Tivo. I always thought Tivo was an outdated product but let me tell you, I couldn't be happier with this product! I have this Tivo Bolt in my main living room and 4 Tivo Mini's throughout the house. I still have Fios but now I have all the movie channels and dropped to a "Custom TV and Sports" package since I never watched all those channels anyway. I immediately started saving about $100 a month on equipment alone and dropping the package to this new one also saved. My cable bill is down to $130 a month with all movie channels! There are complications, there's no on demand so Cinemax, Showtime and Starz are not listed on the Tivo (HBO is), same with local channels but I have an Apple TV and an Amazon Fire TV so between the three, I can use and watch the on demand stuff with the exception of channel 7's on demand, you have to pay for it for some reason. The other's make you sign in with the Fios account and they work. I can even stream them from my phone flawlessly. I also love the Tivo suggestions! I've seen things that I haven't seen in years and would never thought to look for. I love this thing and very, very simple to use. Extremely happy with this purchase, should have done it years ago! My only suggestion to Tivo would be to increase the on demand products.

Great Entry Level DVR with a lot of Capability	Purchased from a B&M retailer. This is my first foray into the Tivo world and so far I am impressed. I had no issues with installation or activation of any services (I have FiOS). My HD and premium stations all work perfectly. The Bolt itself is small and lightweight; considerably smaller than my old STB.It did take a little while to activate but once complete and fully updated, the system is running well. I'm not a hardcore DVR person by any means whatsoever - I just wanted some recording capability and a better interface than the typical Verizon STB and this thing blows it out of the water. There are few apps at the moment but I fully expect this to change in the future. I believe Tivo has a lot in store for the Bolt. Amazon Prime and Netflix work great and integration with the iPhone also works well. 500GB is relatively small for a DVR, but expandable storage is doable via eSata. For me personally, this is a non-issue. Despite the 4K, I don't think this level of storage and 2 fewer tuners are enough for the hardcore DVR users out there, but for those simply wanting a better experience than their cable providers STB, this is a solid way to go.

Love the Bolt, but there are a few things to be aware of....	We mostly love the Tivo Bolt.  We've been using it for about a few months now and here are our thoughts...Things We love:1. SUPER SKIP!!! It is amazing, just push one little button at the start of a commercial break and BAM, you're back to your show!2. 4 Tuners, we only had 2 on our TiVo Premiere 500 GB DVR (Old  Version) - Digital Video Recorder and Streaming Media Player - 2 Tuners and while I didn't think we needed more than 2 tuners most of the time, it was always annoying to miss an episode of a show when schedules got moved around and there were 3 things needing to record.3. We mostly upgraded because we got a free year of service when we purchased, which meant that we could upgrade our Tivo for just $120 if you considered that we were paying $15 a month for service anyways.  And after 6 years we figured a new Tivo for $120 was probably a smart idea in the long run.4. Still works with an Expandable Hard Drive, so we bought the smaller Tivo and transferred our Expandable Hard Drive from the Premiere to the Bolt and it's still compatible.  However we did watch and delete all programming off of it before moving it, Tivo says you can transfer programming in theory, but we couldn't ever get it to work.Things We don't love:1.  You know that spiny wheel that comes up during prime time when too many people are on the internet & Tivo's servers, it's not a software thing with your old Tivo, it still happens with the Bolt, don't buy the Bolt because you think it'll be faster to load, it's just as slow as any other.2. Super Skip doesn't work on all channels or even

Commercial Skip Feature is the Greatest!	After a net realized price increase of 23% to my cable bill I decided enough was enough.  Like many so what if I get a zillion channels. Most of them are never watched because they are useless.  So I started off purchasing an HD antenna to get all that I really wanted which was network channels.I stumbled across the Tivo Bolt and one of many things that got my attention was the "Commercial Skip" feature! After reading about its functionality I thought to myself I "need this feature!"  I despise commercials, especially when most times they are repeated over and over during the same show.  Also, the prescription drug commercials during prime time are on the top of my list for annoying as well.I will be the first to admit that I love my gadgets so to justify this purchase was simply the mathematics.  Since I cancelled cable which resulted in approximately a $50 a month savings. The Tivo Bolt service is $15 a month. Since the current special includes a year of service the net cost equates to a little over $55 bucks for the device. Not bad at all!My Tivo Bolt arrived yesterday and the setup was very easy. It took close to an hour but the majority of that time was downloading and installing updates. The channel scanner located all of my network channels and I was ready to go with no issues or errors.Things I like:1.  Commercial Skip is the best. I feel so empowered when I use it. A victory if you will.2.  I like the one stop shopping for video and entertainment. No more switching input sources, hdmi 1, hdmi 2, etc. to use another source for streaming or subscriptions. Pretty much all

Pleased with the product	Once this is set up and activated, this functions extremely well. The instructions for first time use are minimal, and that can cause delays in getting it operating. For future buyers, please note: 1) Insert cable card, then connect to your cable outlet. After a few minutes, it will start it's own activation process, which is NOT the cable card activation process. 2) After the Bolt setup is complete, you'll need to navigate to CableCard menu screen, and have the information from that screen handy. 3) Call your provider (in my case, Comcast) and give them the card ID #, the Host ID #, and the Data #. Once that is activated, you'll be very pleased with the Bolt's performance and graphic interface, which is a huge improvement over Comcast/Xfinity. Unfortunately, the Tivo Mini that I also ordered was disappointing, due to it's need for 1990's wired technology. I'll write a separate review about that.

First TiVo and loving every aspect of it!	Due to increasing cable costs, I've been trying find ways to cut my bill. For awhile I've been considering getting a TiVo. This would allow me to ditch my cable companies dvr box and dvr service. When I heard about the TiVo Bolt I decided it was time. I've had the TiVo for a week and so far I love this thing. Far more options than I had with my cable supplied dvr box. The TiVo programming and recording is pretty simple. For those considering making the switch you'll find that the TiVo has everything you get from your cable company box, plus a whole lot more. For me the perks are the commercial skip, although not available on every show, it's available on many of the shows I record. Also the QuickPlay feature is good for watching shows that you may have stockpiled. Bing watch in less time. Netflix, YouTube, Amazon Prime, and more are all easily accessible. As well as Spotify (although you need a full membership to access it), I Heart Radio and On Demand (depending on your cable provider). Now, the down side. I set mine up a week ago, it's taken that week to access everything. I had the cable card (required to get your cable channels) I had a wireless connection (required to access the TiVo guide and features). But I couldn't get everything to talk to one another. My first problem was getting the MAC address to talk to my router. My set up requires me to enter the MAC address for whatever I connect wirelessly. However you need to do a software upgrade as soon as you start the TiVo. Not possible if you can't connect wirelessly. I needed to connect thru my Ethernet, then could find

TiVo keeps getting better and better.	I upgraded from a TiVo HD to the TiVo Bolt.The new TiVo Bolt works great with Comcast XFINITY cable TV and the other internet video services I use (like Netflix, Amazon Video and YouTube).I like the speed of the new TiVo. The new user interface, while taking a few days to get used to, is really an improvement.  The new remote control is great (and not having to point it at the TiVo is wonderful!)  The iPhone app works pretty much flawlessly for scheduling and viewing recorded content (and I can use my iPhone as a remote control if I can't find the remote!)  The commercial skip is really effective on the shows that support it.  Configuration with the Comcast cable system was time consuming but straightforward and we experienced no issues there.  There was a little hiccup when I tried connecting the Extender Drive from our old TiVo, but a new cable fixed that and we are up and running with 1.5TB of storage.

Great system that pays for itself.	[Edit 7/16/2016 at end of original]I know Tivo has a reputation for a superb user experience, but it wasn't that that drew me the system.  It was the savings of owning vs renting.  I save $10 a month owning the Bolt & Mini along with the cable card rental fee.  The system pays for itself in under 2 years, and I get the premium UI experience of the Tivo to boot.The Bolt integrates TV & online streaming with a focus on shows.  Favor a TV show, and Bolt will make the seasons available to you across live, recorded, and streaming services. Once you learn to trust it, it's wonderful - you focus on the show, and the Bolt does all the work to assemble the show's seasons for you.Glad to see I wasn't the only one who thought the set up was a bit more of pain than it should have been.  The fault isn't with the equipment - it's the activation process that could have been more verbose to let you know how it was progressing.  The process takes an hour, so set your expectations accordingly.Overall, the Bolt is a great system.  You focus on content, and Bolt does the legwork to find it - all the while saving you money over renting equipment from the cable company.  Recommended.[Edit: Addendum]  One niggle to point out - the YouTube & Hulu apps are a tad buggy, though they seem to be getting better over time.  Youtube use to occasionally error in the middle of videos, but now just quits suddenly after prolonged use.  Hulu can freeze after delivering its commercials.  These problems are deal-killers, but they can be annoying.

Extremely fast, great user interface, awesome Amazon Prime and Netflix integration, cheaper than cable DVR.	I've been very impressed with the Bolt so far. Extremely fast and highly usable. Aside being a top notch DVR, I also love the integration with Amazon Prime and Netflix as well. I've upgraded from FIOS DVR to Xfinity cable-card and it is saving me money over their rental unit, less boxes and cables next to my TV, lower power consumption, and just a significantly better DVR. So far a win, win, win.Not many downsides for me.  Some UI stumbles but it is probably more with my learning the remote rather than a problem with the Tivo.

Glad to be a Tivo user once again	I was a Tivo user long, long ago when it was about the only DVR option for Directv.  Finally had the opportunity recently to become part of the family again when I moved to an area that was serviced by Comcast.  It's great to be back.  Interface is simple and intuitive and it's also great to have access to Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu, etc. from the Tivo menu.  (Now if they could just figure out a way to integrate HBONow.)  After some confusion, I was delighted to discover that the ability to set up a MoCa network was built into the Bolt so adding a Tivo Mini in another room was quick and simple.  Pairing with one of Comcast's cablecards was a bit of an ordeal but, after a few misfires, everything is running smooth.

Great Upgrade	Fantastic upgrade to my Series 3.  I was a bit bummed that I couldn't keep my existing rate, but the free year makes up for it.  The interface is even better and more intuitive than before.  I wish I had made the switch immediately after the release.The Skip Mode is nice, but so rare for what I watch, it's not a huge selling point.  Also, I don't find the One Pass terribly helpful add I don't subscribe to Hulu and it links to Paid Amazon content rather than Prime...So I find it a bit annoying I can't have it recognize what is substitution based vs what I already pay for.  Obviously this is easy to ignite with the click of a button.Swapping cable cards was a snap and quickly recognized.

"Aspect Correction Mode" seals the deal!	My interest was in the terrestrial "Over The Air" capabilities of this tuner. What tickeled my ear was the "Aspect Correction Mode" feature. My internal OTA tuner on my TV would constantly default to "stretch-o-vision" when it came to sources originally filmed in a 4:3 aspect ratio. I found myself constantly accessing a menu for correction. The Tivo was not my first choice and initially purchased a tuner that needed a software upgrade just to make it compatible with my new 4K TV, defaulting to, you guessed it, "stretch-o-vision". Again, constantly having to adjust aspect ratio. What a delight not having to deal with this issue with my new 4K Tivo Bolt.

Love my new TiVo	First, I must say, I love this Tivo box.  That said, here's what I would like enhanced and fixed.1.  It needs more tuners.  I have two minis and I find that sometimes I have to put one in standby to watch live tv on the other.2.  The bolt cannot keep up with the required 30 sec skips all the time and gets locked from further skips.3.  I have a tuning adapter attached to the bolt.  I think it would be an enhancement if there was a "tuning adapter" coax out on the bolt.  It would simply be a moca filtered split from the input coax jack.  That would take all the mis-configuration problems out of using  a tuning adapter.4.  Tivo suggestions need to be a little "smarter".  I constantly delete all the "sports" suggestions and then find them back again.5. The "lifetime" subscription option needs to be revisited.  I expect within 3 to 4 years, TiVo will have more and better equipment offering.  Why would I pay 4 year subscription fees up front to save what I would most likely not need four years later?  If I bought a lifetime subscription, you can guarantee that I will do everything not to have to buy your latest equipment offerings.Finally, overall, I love the bolt and tivo service.  I am saving $36 a month on my Charter bill.

Bolt beats All DVR's	Best DVR we've ever had. Love the universal search option that let's us watch content on Amazon Prime, Plex, HBO and Xfinity streaming.  Of course the standard Tivo features are great and the new commercial skip is awesome. It's been over 10nyears since we've had a Tivo DVR and we're so glad we're back with it now.  We put a Bolt in the living room and a Mini in the master BR and it works better than our old Directv whole home system.

TiVo is back!	I have been a fan of TiVo since their very first DVR and have owned several of them, but was disappointed when I bought the Premiere because it was so slow. When the hard drive failed on it, I simply cancelled my TiVo membership.Not wanting to pay for the crazy cablebox rentals, I started to look for an alternative that could give me HD content (my previous TV did not have an HD tuner), and be able to record my favorite shows. All my searches would bring me back to TiVo, and when I saw the BOLT, I figured I would try it. I'm glad I did!Very fast interface and great features. While all the other TV platforms fight over Amazon Video, TiVo just supports it, as well as Netflix and Hulu.For just a bit more than the price of an HD DVR cablebox from the cable company for 1 year, I get the BOLT, subscription, and so much more.Oh...and of course, it's compatible with my UHD TV, Even tho there's not much content available yet.I plan on extending this BOLT to my other 2 TVs using TiVo MINIs.CONS: Changing between TV and streamed services feels a bit kludgy.  The remote for My new TV was able to control my other devices without even an attempt to program it. Perhaps is done via the HDMI? Not sure. But it was not able to do the TiVo.

Love It!	Loved my Tivo Premiere, love this more. Setup was easy - just paired it with my old cablecard and I was off and running. It's much faster than the Premiere, all the apps work well, and has the benefit of commercial skip which has worked with virtually every current running program. It doesn't work with older programs or recorded movies but that isn't a big deal. The menu is nearly identical to the updated Premiere menu so there was no learning curve. In addition I set up a Mini in my son's room which was an absolute breeze using MoCA. The only problem I encountered was that I had set it on my DVD player (yes, a 9 year old DVD player that works perfectly!) and the heat from the Tivo (which is considerable) caused the DVD player to seize up! A little rearranging after the player cooled down solved the problem. But the heat output is something to keep in mind.For those complaining about the $14.99 a month charge after the first year just keep in mind that it is WAY more than that for the cable company's DVR on a monthly and they don't have anything that equals the Mini which doesn't have any additional monthly charge.

Alittle more than 3 months difference between Direct TV vs my $500 investment in Tivo equipment and I end up with a better viewi	I have been thinking about cutting the cord with Direct TV for awhile.  This along with 3 of their Minis has given me a way to do it.  I have switched to Comcast Business internet foir reliability and to avoid overage fees involved with residential Comcast.  I bought this Tivo along with 3 Minis and a Comcast Cable card.  I now pay less than $50 for cable along with $10 for Netflix vs almost $200 for the Direct TV plus Netflix.  Alittle more than 3 months difference between Direct TV vs my $500 investment in Tivo equipment and  I end up with a better viewing experience and only Pay $50 / month for the Comcast cable card vs $200 for Direct TV.

The ONLY alternative to cable box.	After a long hiatus, I have returned to TiVo after last using a Series 2 many years ago. The wife loves it compared to the kludgy HDHomerun/WMC/NPVR setup I had been running. I wish it used a 3.5" drive instead of 2.5" for larger and cheaper upgrades. The TiVo app for iOS and Android works great. I'm also running the TiVo beta app on my Firestick and it works well enough but I plan on getting a TiVo mini in the near future.I hate the color and design of the box. My favorite feature is the new skip function. It has spoiled me to the point that I wish it was available on all programs.

Love the Tivo Bolt	For over 11 years we had Dish Network satellite TV service and loved it. For reasons I will not go into, last January we switched to Comcast's Xfinity cable TV service which utilizes their "X1" cable box. With a couple exceptions, the Dish Network "Hopper" satellite receiver features were SO much better than those of the X1 cable box, but we had a two year commitment with the Xfinity cable service. Enter the Tivo Bolt. It will take a couple years of not paying the monthly rental on the X1 box to recover the outright purchase cost of the Tivo, but the features of the Tivo are SO much better than those of the X1. Actually, the Tivo features are very similar to those of the Dish Network box with two exceptions. The Tivo also acts as a network streamer for the major providers whereas the Dish box did not. The Dish box featured a "picture in picture" capability whereas the Tivo unfortunately does not. Bottom line though, we love the Tivo Bolt!

so good. A significant upgrade from our 2 Premiers	So far, so good. A significant upgrade from our 2 Premiers. I coupled the BOLT with a TiVo mini which resulted in a great savings as I was paying the monthly service on one Premier plus the fee for the cable card. What I'm saving will pay for the TiVo mini in less than a year. The commercial skip feature is awesome and the menus are much faster. It's also quieter and takes up less space. The funky shape isn't a big deal as it sits right on top of our Blue-Ray player in the entertainment center without any issue. Highly recommend.

Great Product Tivo	I had been hearing the commercials about Tivo Bolt. Well using Comcast Xfinity Basic I found that I need to upgrade to new DVR at $15.00 more per month with Comcast. Well when I worked out the cost, Tivo Bolt was a great deal I purchased the Bolt and installed it. Call Tivo Tech support the tech helped me to setup and even called Comcast Tech to help. I would recommend Tivo Bolt to everyone. When the commercial say that Tivo Bolt replace all the boxes their right. Thank you Tivo!!!!

Works Great In Albuquerque!	First, I want to thank Tivo for having the good sense to wait a few weeks before asking for a review.  (How many times have you bought a product only to have the vendor pester you for a detailed write-up 2-days later?  Give me a break! )  I really can't add any superlatives and major kudos that others haven't already covered. My only complaint has to do with the One Pass programming.  A couple of the new (over-the-air) shows my wife picked (out of many!) never seem to get recorded, even tho we can clearly see them being broadcast on live TV, correct channel & time slot.  (Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, for one.)  I've double-checked the option spec's on these few vanishing shows and don't understand why they won't record, tho I'm sure I'll figure it out in time.  But, back to the pluses . . . this Tivo's a sweetheart, especially in the small details that so many other manufacturers overlook.  True, it's not the cheapest gizmo in town, but most cord-cutters - self included - will make the price back in a mere 2 or 3 months.  Go for it!

Love the "skip" button though still not many shows available ...	Love the "skip" button though still not many shows available for that feature.  Note: the show has to be completely recorded to have the "skip" feature work (i.e. you can't start watching after it's only half over and have the skip feature work).  The "speed" feature is really great - things go faster yet the voices maintain their same pitch.  A recorded football game or even a fast-moving basketball game is easy to watch and you get through it so much faster.  Unit is MUCH smaller than the previous TIVO's and the remote now works with radio frequency so it the TIVO can be behind a closed cabinet and still work fine.  Excellent improvements.

Took gamble on bolt and mini's and it paid off.	I really like my bolt. It's so much better than the my old Comcast cable boxes that didn't have high def. The program guide is so much easier then Comcast layout. I have 2 minis and don't need to pay extra for them, and the bolt also has a dvr where Comcast charges another 20 bucks a month for. I wish the bolt had 6 tuners instead of 4 it would make it easier not to juggle my recordings around. I took a chance with $500 dollars up front coast and, I couldn't be happier. Also had to call Tech support a couple times to get my cable card to work and my 2nd mini connected to my moca network. They came through with flying colors. Thanks, Joel G.

New Tivo Fan	So far so good. We finally cut the cord, cable tv anyways. Its been a long time coming. We used to run wmc until I got tired of fixing and updating it to keep working. Tried xbmc. Its cool, but doesnt meet the wife approval factor. Or WAF if you will.  We have been running plex for awhile now and Tivo and Plex seem to play nice together. Also has the mainstream apps. Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, Spotify, etc. Not a ton of apps, but the main ones. All in all we like it with our Ota antenna. Record 4 at once, cool. Stream, cool, live ota tv from our antenna provides us with 30 channels or so. Loving it. If you only want OTA and streaming. Check out the tivo ota. The Bolt will do cable if you ever decide to go back, and makes a pretty sweet box. We love it!

Newbie DVR user or cable/satellite switcher, this Bolt's for YOU!	My new Bolt is full of features that every TV watcher wants. And while not ALL shows allow the commercial "SKIP" feature, the ones that do make them so much more enjoyable to watch. I love "One Pass". Since I hardly ever watch "live" TV anymore, the ability to set up a recording so easily is awesome. And the options are also awesome. I'm still not able to get one function programmed. A tech support person helped me get it done the right way. She was very helpful. Oh, and the app for my iPhone is awesome too.

Best DVR out there	I absolutely love the BOLT.  I was in a situation where it was going to cost me $25 a month to get a DVR from Comcast. Enter Bolt.  This product came and looked as it does in the picture.  The design is absolutely flawed and looks bizarre but it still looks nice on my entertainment system. The remote seamlessly adapts to your TV and I love how the DVR is always picking stuff it thinks I'll like and gets smarter every day.If you are looking for a DVR, this is your go to.

I love this little machine.	I've had this for a while now and I'm lovin' it. I was basically just looking for a dvr to record my shows while I'm at work. DVR as desired, as it should be!	TiVo has finally offered what it should have all along. Well worth the initial cost.	I had the genie from direct tv. The genie was so slow. Almost unusable at times. So far the bolt is very fast. You press a button and get an immediate response.  This is something that I haven't seen in a cable box in years. My wife can even use it and access Netflix and amazon Instant, something she refused to learn with the genie and roku boxes. I was paying forty three dollars a month to direct tv for the genie and two other tv's. This plus two minis will pay for themselves quickly and give good resale value.

I love this! We cut the cord with our cable ...	I love this!  We cut the cord with our cable company!  We have an antenna for local channels and Netflix (so far) for other channel series & movies.  We are saving $100+ / month.  I also really like the commercial skip for those shows broadcasted with the feature.  It finds the end of them, no fast forwarding and the remote not stopping in time then having to rewind, AND best of all it doesn't jump to the end if you need to fast forward near the end of the show either !!!!  We also purchased TiVo Mini's for a couple of other TVs, which allow us to watch what is on the main unit from anywhere without having to pay hundreds more dollars for the service !!

This TiVo unit has been wonderful I have no cable only antenna and I feel ...	This TiVo unit has been wonderful I have no cable only antenna and I feel like I have cable. fantastic	Absolutely great. I had a series 2, 2 then a premier but ended up selling it as it was just too painfully slow and didn't accommodate multiple rooms without multiple tivos which costs $$$. All of the advertised features work great. Once you use the skip mode you'll wish ...	Pros: All of the advertised features work great. Once you use the skip mode you'll wish it worked on everything. Great Box	I'm a cord cutter and I love this thing. The tuner is faster than my TV's tuner. My only complaint is that I wish it had Sling TV built in along with the Amazon and Netflix that is already there.  Also, it would be nice if you could download new apps like the Roku or the Fire Stick.

Beats Expectations	Was given one year free Xfinity X-1 Voice Activated DVD and returned it to use TIVO Bolt. It's like using my Mac or using a PC, they both "do the same thing," but one does it intuitively and seamlessly. Makes having cable painless.

I would recommend this to anyone who has clunky cable box	Wow! Awsome interface! I would recommend this to anyone who has clunky cable box. So simple! Only drawback is trying to get a good mCArd from the cable company....very painful experience!

great TiVo hardware update	bought this to upgrade my TIVO Premier series. WOW! What a huge leap in functionality. Apps load almost instantly. This is worth the upgrade if you have an older TIVO. While I don't know what the future of DVR's is, this TiVo Bolt is definately best in class!

Easiest Setup Ever	Okay this isn't my first time at the rodeo. From porch to watching cable HD took under one hour. So far the Bolt works as advertised although I wish that the available streaming apps included Dramafever and Viki.  I like being able to watch TV on my iPad.

Hooked on TIVO	I was getting tired of paying so much to Time Warner every month for an HD DVR. Decided to take a gamble and try out TIVO. So far the experience has been great! I love the skip button, and even the suggested shows. I may have even convinced a few friends to jump on board. Even though an annual subscription fee is needed, it still saves me about half of what Time Warner was charging.

Saved a boatload of fees with this baby!	This is the best thing since sliced bread.  I used to have DirecTV, but their fees got out of hand so I dumped them for the cable company. I have 3 Tivo minis that stream the Bolt.Tivo service is $150 a year after the first year, but well worth it in my books.If I get tired of cable, the Bolt will run OTA as well.

The idea that TIVO will show you a show you are looking for on Netflix and Amazon is great as well	I'm loving the TIVO Blot so far, commercial skip, record quality and TIVO menu are exactly as expected they would be. Great system	We cut the cord and are now cable free.  The TiVo allowed us to get shows we couldn't get on antenna alone. Picture is sharp and clear. Very glad to be back to TiVo	Works well with TiVo mini (2) over the Verizon FIOS MoCA 2.0 coax cables in my home. works well, as expected.	This is a really nice product.  I use it to OTA only since I don't have cable. For me, here is the true cost of the Bolt.Price and Tax (purchased from Amazon):  $330.00 less 5% using bank card promotion - $315 less one year's free service $180.00 - less Sale of Tivo Stream whose functionality is built into the Bolt (but missing from Roamio)  $90 - Tivo refunded me back the last month of Roamio which had just begun $15.00 + cost of 2nd remote $30.00. It can easily be seen the upgrade didn't cost me much.What am I doing w/two remotes operating Tivo?  Won't say, but hint - the remote uses RF to control the Tivo box.Performance/Aesthetic/UI Improvements:- Remote is white and does not show dirt, it seems ligher, the quality of the Tivo button in particular is improved- UI now uses a more modern white background- The white curved Tivo is very cool looking. Much cooler than the Roamio- Have not tested the commercial skip feature - its vaporware  unless you watch soap operas during the day. Would have been really handy during the Republican Presidential debate- The UI is much faster. Screens snap. Everything is faster-Streaming in 2nd room is much faster. Faster queuing and less buffering-wifi is much faster-Tivo refunded me back the last month of Roamio which had just begun.Definately worth upgrading!Update:  Suddenly as I began to fast-forward, a prompt appeared asking me if I wanted to skip the commercial by hitting D on my remote. EXCEEDS EXPECTATIONS !!	I can't say enough about how much I (we) love this system. Even my wife who gives me sh** ..... a hard time  when I buy new tech stuff,  absolutely loves this. WHAT A GREAT DEVICE	I dropped AT&T Uverse TV.  What I really liked about it was the DVR from them.  I hated giving that up.  Then I read about TIVO.  The more I read the more I liked the idea. the skip and fast speed features are great. Really happy with this purchase	I was hesitant to upgrade from my old TiVo Premiere, since there was nothing wrong with it. Great upgrade from the Roamio!	These are my favorite features:1. It's much faster than my Romio, specially Netflix which loads instantly ! Hidden Diamond of Value	Excellent commercial skipping-Aggregates Hulu netflix -good youtube app-Pandora....much better than cable company dvrs! If I cant get promo rates I cancel & my wife simply becomes new subscriber getting promo rates.  Also when you back out the cost of the 1 yr service included $280-$150(would pay more anyway to cable company) and the cost of stream function already included ($130) essentially the box is free. Just awesome	I've owned the Bolt for about 3 weeks now, and have added 2 Minis, one at a time, since.  It was a somewhat rocky road getting all of the devices configured - especially the Minis, but it was worth it.  The user experience, compared to the FIOS, is like fast forwarding 10 years into the future.  Just the ability to block stations you never want to see again is awesome.  It's fast, intuitive, and fun.  About half the shows I've recorded respond to the "Skip" button on the remote, which skips all commercials perfectly.  Wow!  I'm not sure why, but the picture and especially the sound quality has greatly improved.  Most everything is Dolby Digital now - it wasn't before.  And I love not paying $50 at month for the big clunky FIOS boxes and those awful remotes.  In about 12 months, I'll hit the break even for all of the Tivo equipment, and at that point will just be paying $15 a month to Tivo for their service, and whatever FIOS gets for a single cable card, which is all you'll need for your entire TIVO network.Most of my setup difficulties came from Tivo's assumption that if you are a FIOS customer, you are already MOCA enabled.  I wasn't, and caused a lot of headaches.  There's an easy way to tell - if your FIOS router has an ethernet connection coming in, you're not MOCA enabled.  FIOS can set that up for you remotely.  Once you are, makes sure there's no ethernet cable connected to your Bolt - as internet connectivity will also be coming in through the coax cable.  If there is, the Bolt will work fine, but the Minis won't.Tivo rocks!
